text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

I know this flexibility was one
of the things that attracted
you to the master's program.

So let's start with why it
was important to you as well

as your other
reasons for applying.

As you said, the flexibility
was one of the main reasons

or important factors of wanting
to come and do this program.

I was looking for a program
that would be flexible in both,

potentially, how the
program was delivered,

where it could be in-person,
could be remote, and then

the duration of it, where I
could do it short if I want to,

or I could take a few
years, or I could kind of

go in and out if I'm working
on other work projects.

And then also content-wise,
I wanted something

that was flexible, that would
let me kind of pick and choose
topics.

I mean, I'd have a kind of
a concentration of areas

that I was interested
in but would also

allow me to focus on other
kind of tangential areas
that I thought were interesting.

It was also really good
from a work point of view,
because I was able to--

some quarters be able to take
more classes than others.

And then also be able
to tailor the classes

I wanted around what
my work schedule was.

I was working in
management consulting
for the first little while.

So I actually was able
to use some of my classes

for projects that
I was working on.

I would like,
choose a class that

was specifically similar to
the project I was working on.

And so, yeah, I
mean, my papers were
similar to my work outputs.
Yeah.

I know that's something
that a lot of our students

really appreciate when
they're in the HCP program

is that they can
immediately apply
what they've been learning.

So do you have any specific
examples of something

that correlated like that or
kind of within a few months?
Oh, yeah.
Absolutely.

I mean, a couple
of examples apply.

So one of them was working
on a consulting project.
It was with an HR department.

And we were working on
a performance management
consulting project.

And so there's HR classes
that you can or have to take.

So taking Bob Sutton's
or behavior class
really valuable for that.

Another one I was
working on a startup.
And we needed to do--

like I was in
charge of marketing.

So I took the global
entrepreneurial marketing class

and got, I think, there were
four or five other people

on my team working
on the project.

And literally,
the entire project

was all of the deliverables
I was doing for my work.

And so, yeah, it ended
up being really nice.
Yeah.

It also is nice because
for your homework,

you then have coworkers
reviewing your homework
and giving feedback on it.

But also for your
work deliverables,

you have classmates
and professors

or advisors giving
kind of feedback on it.

So it's-- yeah, it was a
nice kind of virtuous cycle

and getting feedback
and doing well on that.

I mean, the other thing
that's nice, too, is, I mean,

it's kind of like all the
boundaries between those three

groups the co-term, the
external master's, and the HCP
are kind of porous.
Like you can go back and forth.

So I mean, I did my first three
classes as HCP or NDO student

and then I moved to a full
time master's student.

And then I did
that for the next--
I don't know-- 25, 30 credits.

And then for the
last little while,

I've switched back
to an HCP student.

I mean, it's really nice to
be able to go back and forth.
And like--
It really is.

That's why in our
admissions procedures,

we ask the question,
but it's just something

that we're not huge, because
people can switch backwards

and forwards kind of as needed
during the program, which
is really nice.

And so it's the same
admissions criteria.

It's all the same
degree as well.

And then just the NDO that
you've been mentioning,
the non-degree option.
Yeah.

I mean, one of the
trade-offs of like being

the NDO or the full
HCP is you can use that

as a supplement to
whatever else you're doing.

so if you're working, these
classes supplement your work.

A lot of people who are coming
back to a master's program,

whether it's HCP or
whether it's the full-time

master's, they're
coming back for--

I mean, there's
a lot of reasons,
but often want to learn a lot.
You like learning.

You got that
intellectual curiosity.
Yeah.
A lot of curiosity there.

You didn't have the career
opportunities you wanted,
right out of undergraduate.

And so you're like, well,
what could amplify that?

So those are probably two
of the most common reasons
why I see people coming back.
And they're pretty generous--
A career pivot.
Yeah.

Actually, that is the other
one is a career pivot.
You see you see those three.

I mean, overall, it was
an amazing experience.
